ygData.subject: Re: Request for Comments: Geographical and Behavioural Space Considerations
ygData.msgSnippet: Hi Colin, your idea of implementing some kind of location in a 2d space for each agent sounds interesting. Just to assure that I understand you correct: you

Hi Colin,

your idea of implementing some kind of location in a 2d space fo=
r each agent sounds interesting. 

Just to assure that I understand you cor=
rect: you are working with objective fitness functions, not a co-evolution =
approach where a geo-location might also play an important role!?

You wrot=
e, population density should adjust the fitness. This means, two species ca=
nnot share the same area (or don't you use the concept of species)!?

Do yo=
u aim to model something in analogy to nature? Then, I don't get the link. =
In natural systems (which is based on co-evolution and open-ended) the loca=
tion on earth determines what is the predator and what is the prey, and whi=
ch environmental properties must be incorporated in the evolutionary develo=
pment. In the simulation that you aim to setup (if I understand you correct=
ly), it seems that you would like to use the geo-location to create more di=
versity for your objective search!?

Best,
Martin


--- In neat@yahoogroups=
.com, Colin Green <colin.green1@...> wrote:
>
> Hi all,
> 
> I'm starting t=
o think about direction for the next SharpNEAT
> iteration. There's been a =
lot of talk recently about novelty search
> versus objective search, and ma=
ybe mixtures of the two. I myself
> talked about how in the natural world o=
rganisms are separated in both
> behavioural space (i.e. novel behaviour is=
 less likely to compete for
> the same resources as existing behaviours) bu=
t also geographical
> space, and I think that geographical space is a key f=
actor that is
> missing from NEAT based search currently, and possibly EC a=
s a whole,
> with the caveat there may be other research groups with work i=
n that
> area that I'm unaware of.
> 
> My current plan is to focus on this=
 geographical space idea for this
> iteration because it is the simplest to=
 implement. Dealing with
> behavioural space is potentially more complicate=
d because how to
> compare behaviour varies across problem domains and how =
you identify
> the key factors to compare is probably a non-trivial problem=
. I want
> to try and tackle this at some point, but I'm also keen to explo=
re the
> geo-space idea.
> 
> What does this all mean in practical terms?
>=
 
> SharpNEAT is a kit of parts that allows you to swap in replacement
> pa=
rts such as an alternative genetic representation and/or associated
> genet=
ic operators (recombination, mutation, etc) with minimal impact
> on other =
parts in the kit (in principle anyway). I'm proposing to
> provide an alter=
native evolution algorithm class that replaces NEAT's
> genome based specia=
tion (which clusters genomes into K clusters in
> genetic space), with a ge=
ographical space alternative (I'll call it
> geo-space for short).
> 
> The=
 idea is that we have some cartesian/euclidean space (probably a
> square 2=
D space initially to keep the code simple, but 3D or 'globe'
> space (2-sph=
ere) are reasonable alternatives). The seed genomes are
> each assigned a r=
andom coord in the geo-space and this will be fixed
> for the life of that =
genome. So we are basically adding a physical
> attribute to the genome suc=
h that our population members are probably
> better referred to as organism=
s (or agents or population members).
> I'll use 'agent' because it's easier=
 to type :)
> 
> Agent fitness is now adjusted by population density at the=
 agent's
> geo-location, this allows really bad agents to survive so long a=
s they
> are in a sparse region of geo-space, thus allowing for some divers=
ity
> of the genome pool.
> 
> Reproduction - I haven't put much thought in=
to this but the two
> options I see are to create offspring agents near to =
their parent(s)
> versus randomly scattered. Probably some 'dispersion' var=
iable will
> define the amount of scattering with 0 being atop of the paren=
t (or
> between the two?) and 1 being totally random. (Question: Is e.g. se=
ed
> scattering in nature gaussian?). Clearly if agent's are spawned near
>=
 their parent's we would expect to see clusters of agent's with similar
> b=
ehaviour, and that clustering will increase population density and
> theref=
ore lower the fitness of agent's in that cluster. So there is a
> form of f=
itness sharing going on, but as I say, I haven't really
> thought through t=
he implications and dynamics of that. But it would be
> interesting to set =
up, play with and observe what happens.
> 
> Factoring in behavioural space=
 considerations should be possible at a
> later date, e.g. fitness at a geo=
-location is not adjusted down if an
> agent has novel behaviour compared t=
o other agent's at that
> geo-location.
> 
> As per usual - any thoughts an=
d feedback are welcome.
> 
> Colin
>
